model_name: Human-Assisted Intelligence Assurance Maturity Model (HAIAMM) v2.0
description: A comprehensive maturity model for securing Human-Assisted Intelligence (HAI) systems across six critical domains: Software, Infrastructure, Endpoints, Data, Processes, and Vendors. Adapted from OWASP SAMM to address the unique security challenges of AI-augmented systems. [v2.1-pilot: Reduced from 702 to 468 questions for improved efficiency while with 12 core practices] [v2.1-pilot: Outcome-oriented enhancements for SM, ST, TA in Software domain]

domains.name: Software Domain
domains.description: Security of software applications and code in HAI systems, including AI model code, integration layers, and custom applications

practices.name: Strategy & Metrics
practices.objective: Ensure Strategy & Metrics for HAI software
practices.description: Strategy & Metrics practices specific to HAI software

maturity_levels.objective: Establish foundational understanding and oversight of AI security operations across the organization
activities: Create comprehensive inventory of all AI security agents (deployed and planned)
Define organizational risk tolerance for AI-operated security
Establish executive sponsorship for AI security program
Implement basic metrics tracking AI agent activities

assessment_criteria.question: Do you have a documented strategy for AI security operations?
verification: Review AI security strategy document (must be <12 months old)
Verify document includes: AI agent inventory, risk tolerance, governance structure
Interview executive sponsor to confirm awareness and engagement
Check if strategy is communicated to relevant teams
evidence: AI security strategy document with approval signatures
AI agent inventory spreadsheet/database
Executive sponsor assignment documentation
Meeting minutes from quarterly executive reviews (last 2 quarters)

scoring.yes_if: Document exists, is current (<12mo), includes required elements, has executive sponsor
scoring.partial_if: Document exists but missing elements or outdated
scoring.no_if: No documented strategy or >12 months old

assessment_criteria.question: Are AI agent activities aligned with organizational risk tolerance?
verification: Review risk classification of AI security agents (high/medium/low risk)
Check if high-risk agents have appropriate oversight controls
Verify human approval required for high-risk AI decisions
Sample 5 recent AI agent decisions, confirm alignment with risk policy
evidence: Risk classification matrix for AI security agents
Policy document defining risk thresholds
Examples of human-in-loop controls for high-risk decisions
Audit log showing human approvals for high-risk AI actions

scoring.yes_if: AI agents classified by risk, appropriate controls exist, evidence of enforcement
scoring.partial_if: Risk classification exists but controls inconsistent
scoring.no_if: No risk classification or AI agents operate without risk-based controls

success_metrics.target: >80% of AI security agents documented
success_metrics.measurement: (Documented AI agents / Total deployed AI agents) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: AI agent inventory database + IT asset management
success_metrics.baseline: Conduct initial discovery to establish baseline
success_metrics.validation: Cross-check with vendor licenses, cloud service logs, security tool inventory

success_metrics.target: 100% of C-suite can name at least 3 AI security agents in use
success_metrics.measurement: Survey/interview C-level executives
success_metrics.data_source: Executive interviews or anonymous survey
success_metrics.baseline: Initial survey before AI security strategy implementation
success_metrics.validation: Ask specific questions: 'What AI tools make security decisions?'

success_metrics.target: Track at least 3 KPIs for AI security operations
success_metrics.measurement: Count of active KPI dashboards/reports
success_metrics.data_source: Metrics tracking system (dashboard, BI tool, spreadsheet)
success_metrics.validation: KPIs must include: # decisions made, coverage %, uptime/availability

success_metrics.target: >70% of sampled AI security decisions align with risk policy
success_metrics.measurement: Sample 20 recent AI decisions, assess alignment with risk tolerance
success_metrics.data_source: AI agent decision logs + risk policy
success_metrics.validation: Independent review by risk team or audit

desired_outcomes: Leadership Accountability: C-suite and senior leadership understand what AI agents are doing security work
Risk-Based Oversight: AI security activities categorized by risk level with appropriate human oversight
Measurement Foundation: Basic visibility into AI security agent activities and foundation for effectiveness tracking
Inventory Clarity: Organization knows which AI agents are operating security functions with no 'shadow AI'
common_pitfalls: Incomplete Inventory: Missing shadow AI tools, not including planned agents, forgetting AI features in existing tools
Strategy Without Teeth: Beautiful document nobody follows, no enforcement mechanism
Risk Classification Too Broad: All agents marked 'medium risk' to avoid decisions
Metrics Theater: Tracking vanity metrics instead of effectiveness
tools_resources: Asset management platforms (ServiceNow, Jira)
Cloud service discovery (AWS Config, Azure Resource Graph)
BI/Dashboard tools (Tableau, Power BI, Grafana)
Reference: OpenSAMM v1.0 Strategy & Metrics, NIST CSF, ISO/IEC 42001

maturity_levels.objective: Align AI security agent operations with business risk priorities and measure effectiveness (not just activity)
activities: Classify AI security agents by criticality and business impact
Map AI agent activities to business risk areas
Establish effectiveness KPIs (not just activity metrics)
Create AI security ROI dashboard for leadership
Implement regular strategy reviews with stakeholders

assessment_criteria.question: Are AI security components classified by risk and business criticality?
verification: Review risk classification matrix (must include business impact)
Check if high-risk assets have appropriate AI security coverage
Verify business process mapping to AI security agents
Sample 10 assets: Confirm risk rating drives AI coverage decisions
evidence: Risk classification matrix with business impact scores
Asset inventory with criticality ratings
AI security coverage map (which agents protect which assets)
Decision documentation showing risk-based prioritization

scoring.yes_if: Comprehensive risk classification exists, drives coverage decisions, business impact included
scoring.partial_if: Risk classification exists but not consistently used for decisions
scoring.no_if: No risk-based classification or AI coverage not aligned with risk

assessment_criteria.question: Are security goals tailored for different types of AI agents?
verification: Review AI agent categories (testing, monitoring, compliance, etc.)
Check if each category has specific effectiveness goals
Verify goals are measurable and tracked
Interview AI agent owners: Do they know their goals?
evidence: Goals documentation by AI agent type
KPI tracking for each AI agent category
Performance dashboards showing goal achievement
Stakeholder interviews confirming goal awareness

scoring.yes_if: Tailored goals exist for each AI agent type, are tracked, stakeholders aware
scoring.partial_if: Some goals exist but not comprehensive or not tracked
scoring.no_if: One-size-fits-all goals or no specific goals by agent type

assessment_criteria.question: Do you measure AI security agent goal achievement with effectiveness metrics?
verification: Review metrics dashboard: Must include effectiveness (not just activity)
Check for true/false positive tracking
Verify time-to-detection and coverage metrics exist
Sample 3 AI agents: Can you show their effectiveness over time?
evidence: Effectiveness metrics dashboard (screenshots or access)
True positive/false positive rate reports (last 3 months)
Coverage analysis showing % of attack surface monitored
Time-series data showing improvement/decline in effectiveness

scoring.yes_if: Comprehensive effectiveness metrics tracked, data shows trends, used for decisions
scoring.partial_if: Some effectiveness metrics exist but incomplete or not used
scoring.no_if: Only activity metrics (# of scans, # of alerts) without effectiveness

success_metrics.target: >80% of high-risk assets have appropriate AI security agent coverage
success_metrics.measurement: (High-risk assets with AI coverage / Total high-risk assets) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: Asset inventory + AI security coverage mapping
success_metrics.validation: Independent review by risk management team

success_metrics.target: Quarterly strategy reviews with >80% attendance from key stakeholders
success_metrics.measurement: Attendance rate at quarterly AI security strategy meetings
success_metrics.data_source: Meeting attendance records
success_metrics.validation: Meeting minutes, action item tracking

success_metrics.metric: AI Agent Effectiveness - True Positive Rate
success_metrics.target: >70% of AI-reported security issues are valid (true positives)
success_metrics.measurement: (Validated issues / Total AI-reported issues) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: Issue tracking system with validation status
success_metrics.validation: Manual validation by security analysts

success_metrics.target: >60% of attack surface monitored by AI security agents
success_metrics.measurement: (Monitored attack surface / Total attack surface) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: Attack surface inventory + AI agent coverage matrix
success_metrics.validation: Cross-check with penetration test findings

success_metrics.target: Can demonstrate cost/benefit ratio of AI security investments
success_metrics.measurement: Calculate: (Risk reduced in $) / (AI security tool costs in $)
success_metrics.data_source: Risk quantification + tool costs + effectiveness data
success_metrics.validation: Validated by finance and risk management

desired_outcomes: Risk-Driven Investment: AI security spending prioritized by business risk, not vendor hype
Measurable Effectiveness: Know which AI agents perform well vs. poorly with data-driven improvement
Board-Ready Metrics: Executive dashboards showing AI security value with clear ROI story
Strategic Alignment: AI security operations aligned with business objectives, seen as enabler not cost center
common_pitfalls: Vanity Metrics: Only tracking metrics that look good, ignoring problems
No Baseline: Reporting metrics without historical comparison
Risk Classification Theater: Everything marked same risk level
Metrics Without Action: Dashboards created but never reviewed or acted upon
tools_resources: FAIR (Factor Analysis of Information Risk)
Security metrics platforms (CISO Dash, Panaseer)
Custom BI dashboards (Tableau, Power BI)
ROI calculators, Threat modeling tools

maturity_levels.objective: Continuously optimize AI security operations through data-driven decisions, industry benchmarking, and predictive analytics
activities: Benchmark AI security spending and effectiveness against industry peers
Correlate AI security investments with actual risk reduction outcomes
Optimize AI agent portfolio based on effectiveness and ROI data
Establish feedback loops from security incidents to AI agent improvement
Implement predictive analytics for AI security effectiveness

assessment_criteria.question: Are AI security costs benchmarked against industry standards?
verification: Review benchmarking data from at least 3 peer organizations or industry reports
Check if organization participates in benchmarking programs
Verify AI security spend as % of total security budget is tracked
Compare effectiveness metrics (true positive rate, coverage) to peers
evidence: Benchmarking reports from last 12 months
Peer comparison data (anonymized)
Industry benchmark sources (HAIAMM community, Gartner, etc.)
Internal analysis comparing org performance to benchmarks

scoring.yes_if: Regular benchmarking against 3+ sources, data drives decisions, documented comparisons
scoring.partial_if: Some benchmarking but infrequent or not comprehensive
scoring.no_if: No benchmarking or only anecdotal comparisons

assessment_criteria.question: Do you track historical AI security expenditure and correlate with outcomes?
verification: Review historical spend data (3+ years if available)
Check correlation analysis between spend and risk reduction
Verify outcome metrics tracked over same time period
Analyze: Can you show ROI improved year-over-year?
evidence: Multi-year AI security spend tracking
Risk reduction quantification over time
ROI calculation methodology documentation
Trend analysis showing spend effectiveness correlation

scoring.yes_if: 3+ years historical data, correlation analysis performed, ROI trends documented
scoring.partial_if: Some historical tracking but limited correlation analysis
scoring.no_if: No historical tracking or no correlation to outcomes

assessment_criteria.question: Are AI security investments demonstrably aligned with risk reduction?
verification: Review investment decisions from last 12 months
Check if risk quantification drove investment priority
Verify post-implementation: Did investment reduce target risk?
Sample 3 major AI security investments: Show risk reduction achieved
evidence: Investment proposals with risk quantification
Post-implementation reviews showing risk reduction
Business cases with ROI projections vs. actuals
Portfolio optimization decisions based on ROI data

scoring.yes_if: Investments driven by risk quantification, post-validation performed, demonstrable alignment
scoring.partial_if: Some risk-based decision making but not consistent
scoring.no_if: Investments ad-hoc or not validated against risk reduction

success_metrics.target: Compare AI security performance against at least 3 peer organizations annually
success_metrics.measurement: Count of benchmarking exercises completed per year
success_metrics.data_source: Benchmarking reports, HAIAMM community data, industry surveys
success_metrics.validation: Documented benchmark reports with peer comparisons

success_metrics.target: Show $X risk reduction per $Y invested in AI security (target: >3:1 ratio)
success_metrics.measurement: (Quantified risk reduction in $) / (AI security spend in $)
success_metrics.data_source: Risk quantification + financial tracking + effectiveness data
success_metrics.validation: Finance and risk management validated, auditable

success_metrics.target: At least 2 data-driven AI agent portfolio decisions per year (replace/retire/add)
success_metrics.measurement: Count of portfolio changes with documented ROI rationale
success_metrics.data_source: Investment decision records, business cases
success_metrics.validation: Business case documentation, post-decision review

success_metrics.target: AI security needs forecasts within 20% of actual (6-month ahead)
success_metrics.measurement: (|Forecasted need - Actual need| / Actual need) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: Forecast documents vs. actual resource utilization
success_metrics.baseline: Begin forecasting, measure accuracy after 6 months
success_metrics.validation: Compare forecast to actual spending, resource allocation

success_metrics.target: 10% annual improvement in AI security effectiveness/cost ratio
success_metrics.measurement: ((This year effectiveness/cost) - (Last year effectiveness/cost)) / (Last year) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: Historical effectiveness metrics + spend tracking
success_metrics.baseline: Requires 2 years of data to establish trend
success_metrics.validation: Consistent methodology year-over-year, externally validated

desired_outcomes: Optimized AI Security Spending: Every dollar delivers maximum risk reduction, low-ROI tools replaced
Proactive Security Posture: Anticipate needs before gaps emerge, plan 6-12 months ahead
Industry-Leading Maturity: Demonstrably in top quartile for effectiveness
Continuous Improvement Culture: Regular optimization based on data, year-over-year progress
Competitive Advantage: Superior AI security operations enable business growth with trust advantage

breakdown.benchmarking_setup: 40-60 hours (identify peers, join programs, collect data)
breakdown.portfolio_optimization: 80-120 hours (evaluate all AI agents, business cases, decisions)

common_pitfalls: Benchmarking Bias: Only compare against weaker peers to look good
ROI Fabrication: Claiming risk reduction without evidence
Analysis Paralysis: Too much data collection, not enough action
Predictive Inaccuracy: Forecasts based on flawed assumptions not updated as conditions change
tools_resources: HAIAMM community benchmarking database (when launched)
Industry benchmark reports (Gartner, Forrester, SANS)
Portfolio management software, ROI calculators
BI tools with forecasting (Power BI, Tableau), Statistical analysis (R, Python)

practices.name: Threat Assessment
practices.objective: Ensure Threat Assessment for HAI software
practices.description: Threat Assessment practices specific to HAI software

maturity_levels.objective: Identify basic threats to AI security operations and establish foundational threat awareness
activities: Create threat model for AI security agent deployments
Assess threats specific to AI agents (beyond traditional threats)
Prioritize threats by likelihood and business impact
Establish baseline threat awareness across security team

assessment_criteria.question: Do you create threat models for AI security agent deployments?
verification: Review threat model documentation for AI security agents
Check if threat models cover AI-specific threats (not just traditional)
Verify threat models created within last 12 months
Interview security team: Are they aware of threat models?
evidence: Threat model documents for AI security agents (last 12 months)
STRIDE or similar analysis framework applied to AI agents
List of identified threats specific to AI security operations
Security team training records on AI threats

scoring.yes_if: Current threat models exist, cover AI-specific threats, team aware
scoring.partial_if: Some threat modeling but outdated or incomplete
scoring.no_if: No threat models for AI security agents

assessment_criteria.question: Do you consider threats specific to AI agents (prompt injection, model poisoning, etc.)?
verification: Review threat model: Does it include AI-specific attack vectors?
Check for documentation of: Prompt injection, data poisoning, adversarial evasion
Verify threat scenarios consider AI agent failures/compromises
Sample 3 AI agents: Do threat models cover AI-specific risks?
evidence: Threat model sections addressing AI-specific threats
MITRE ATLAS or similar AI threat framework reference
Scenarios documenting AI agent compromise impact
Comparison: AI threats vs. traditional threats coverage

scoring.yes_if: Comprehensive AI-specific threat coverage, documented scenarios, frameworks used
scoring.partial_if: Some AI-specific threats but not comprehensive
scoring.no_if: Only traditional threats, no AI-specific threat consideration

success_metrics.target: >80% of AI security agents have documented threat models
success_metrics.measurement: (AI agents with threat models / Total AI security agents) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: Threat model repository + AI agent inventory
success_metrics.validation: Audit threat models for completeness, recency

success_metrics.target: Identify >10 unique AI-specific threats to security operations
success_metrics.measurement: Count of documented AI-specific threats
success_metrics.data_source: Threat model documentation
success_metrics.validation: Threats mapped to MITRE ATLAS or similar framework

success_metrics.target: 100% of identified threats have risk scores (likelihood × impact)
success_metrics.measurement: (Threats with risk scores / Total identified threats) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: Threat register with risk scoring
success_metrics.validation: Risk scoring methodology documented, consistent

success_metrics.target: >80% of security team can name 3 AI-specific threats
success_metrics.measurement: Survey/quiz security team members
success_metrics.data_source: Training assessment or anonymous survey
success_metrics.validation: Independent training assessment

desired_outcomes: AI Threat Awareness: Security team understands AI agents have unique threat vectors, not treating AI security like traditional security
Risk-Based Prioritization: Know which AI security threats pose highest business risk, resources focused on biggest threats first
Documented Baseline: Threat models exist for reference, foundation for maturity improvement
Accountability: Clear ownership for monitoring each AI threat with alert/escalation procedures

breakdown.threat_modeling: 30-50 hours (threat model creation for all AI agents)

common_pitfalls: Generic Threat Models: Using traditional templates, missing AI-specific threats entirely
Threat Modeling Theater: Beautiful models created but never used, no follow-up
No Prioritization: All threats treated equally, or only fixing easy threats
Awareness Lip Service: Training is forwarding an article with no validation of learning
tools_resources: Threat modeling tools (Microsoft Threat Modeling Tool, OWASP Threat Dragon, IriusRisk)
AI threat frameworks (MITRE ATLAS, NIST AI RMF Playbook, OWASP AI Security Guide)
Training (AI security courses, hands-on labs)
Risk scoring (FAIR, DREAD framework, custom matrices)

maturity_levels.objective: Develop comprehensive threat scenarios for AI security operations and integrate threat intelligence
activities: Develop detailed attack scenarios (abuse cases) for AI agents
Integrate threat intelligence feeds for AI-specific threats
Assess supply chain threats to AI security tools
Prioritize threats by actual exploitability (not just theoretical)
Establish threat trend analysis and reporting

assessment_criteria.question: Do you develop abuse cases (attack scenarios) for AI security agents?
verification: Review abuse case documentation (should be detailed, not generic)
Check coverage: >80% of high-risk AI agents have abuse cases
Verify testing: Have abuse cases been tested (not just documented)?
Sample 3 abuse cases: Are they realistic and detailed?
evidence: Abuse case library with attack scenarios
Testing results: Can our controls prevent these attacks?
Coverage mapping: Which AI agents have abuse cases
Realism validation: SME review of scenario feasibility

scoring.yes_if: Comprehensive abuse cases exist, tested, cover high-risk agents, realistic
scoring.partial_if: Some abuse cases but limited coverage or not tested
scoring.no_if: No documented abuse cases or purely theoretical

assessment_criteria.question: Do you integrate AI threat intelligence into your threat assessment?
verification: Review threat intelligence sources subscribed to
Check if AI-specific threat intel is monitored
Verify threat models updated based on new intelligence
Confirm alerts configured for relevant AI threats
evidence: Threat intelligence subscriptions list (AI-focused)
Threat model update history (intelligence-driven)
Alert rules for AI-specific threat indicators
Examples of threat model changes based on new intelligence

scoring.yes_if: Active threat intelligence integration, regular updates, automated alerts
scoring.partial_if: Some threat intelligence but not systematically integrated
scoring.no_if: No AI-specific threat intelligence integration

assessment_criteria.question: Do you assess supply chain threats to AI security tools?
verification: Review AI security tool vendor assessments
Check if dependency risks documented (libraries, APIs, data sources)
Verify supply chain threat mitigation strategies exist
Sample 3 AI tool vendors: Supply chain risk assessment completed?
evidence: Vendor security assessment documentation
Software bill of materials (SBOM) for AI tools
Supply chain threat scenarios (vendor compromise, malicious updates)
Mitigation controls (vendor requirements, code review, sandboxing)

scoring.yes_if: Comprehensive supply chain assessment, documented risks, mitigation in place
scoring.partial_if: Some vendor assessment but not systematic or incomplete
scoring.no_if: No supply chain threat consideration for AI tools

success_metrics.target: >80% of high-risk AI security agents have documented and tested abuse cases
success_metrics.measurement: (High-risk agents with tested abuse cases / Total high-risk agents) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: Abuse case library + testing results
success_metrics.validation: Independent review of abuse case realism and testing

success_metrics.target: Threat models updated within 30 days of relevant new AI threat intelligence
success_metrics.measurement: Time from intelligence publication to threat model update
success_metrics.data_source: Threat intelligence feed timestamps + threat model change log
success_metrics.validation: Audit threat model update timeliness

success_metrics.target: 100% of AI security tool vendors have completed security assessments
success_metrics.measurement: (Vendors with security assessments / Total AI tool vendors) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: Vendor assessment tracking system
success_metrics.validation: Assessment quality review, third-party validation

success_metrics.target: >70% of high-priority threats have exploitability validation (PoC tested)
success_metrics.measurement: (High-priority threats with PoC / Total high-priority threats) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: Threat register with PoC testing status
success_metrics.validation: PoC documentation, ethical testing procedures

desired_outcomes: Realistic Threat Understanding: Know exactly how attacks would unfold, not just 'prompt injection is a risk'
Intelligence-Driven Security: Threat models reflect current landscape, early warning for new AI threats
Supply Chain Visibility: Understand dependencies and vendor risks, prepared for compromise scenarios
Efficient Resource Allocation: Focus on practically exploitable threats, not theoretical FUD

implementation.cost_external: $60K-$120K (threat modeling consultants, red team for PoC, vendor assessments)

common_pitfalls: Abuse Cases Without Testing: Documenting scenarios but never testing if they work
Threat Intelligence Overload: Subscribe to 20 feeds, can't process the volume
Supply Chain Theater: Vendor questionnaires that vendors lie on with no validation
PoC Without Ethics: Testing exploits against production without approval
tools_resources: Attack trees, MITRE ATT&CK Navigator
AI-specific threat feeds (Recorded Future, ThreatConnect), OSINT tools
SBOM tools (Syft, CycloneDX), vendor assessment platforms
Proof-of-concept frameworks, isolated testing environments

maturity_levels.objective: Proactively predict and prepare for future AI security threats through advanced modeling, intelligence analysis, and industry collaboration
activities: Conduct advanced AI security threat modeling including zero-day scenarios
Participate in AI security threat intelligence sharing communities
Establish predictive threat modeling for emerging AI technologies
Integrate threat assessment with business continuity planning
Publish anonymized AI threat research to advance industry knowledge

assessment_criteria.question: Do you conduct advanced threat modeling including multi-stage and zero-day scenarios?
verification: Review advanced threat models (beyond simple STRIDE)
Check for zero-day preparedness scenarios
Verify cascade/chain attack modeling (compromised AI agent impacts)
Validate business continuity integration
evidence: Advanced threat model documentation (attack trees, kill chains)
Zero-day response procedures for AI agents
Cascade analysis reports
Business continuity plan with AI security failure scenarios

scoring.yes_if: Comprehensive advanced modeling, zero-day prep, cascade analysis, BCP integrated
scoring.partial_if: Some advanced modeling but not comprehensive
scoring.no_if: Only basic threat modeling, no advanced scenarios

assessment_criteria.question: Do you participate in AI security threat intelligence sharing communities?
verification: Review ISAC or similar community memberships
Check if organization contributes (not just receives) intelligence
Verify active participation (attending meetings, sharing insights)
Confirm value: Examples of actionable intelligence received
evidence: Community membership documentation (ISACs, industry groups)
Examples of threat intelligence shared by organization
Meeting attendance records or participation proof
Case studies: Intelligence received that drove security improvements

scoring.yes_if: Active community participation, bi-directional sharing, demonstrable value
scoring.partial_if: Passive membership or infrequent participation
scoring.no_if: No community participation

assessment_criteria.question: Do you conduct predictive threat modeling for emerging AI technologies?
verification: Review emerging technology monitoring process
Check if threat models exist for not-yet-deployed AI technologies
Verify research into future AI security threats (3-5 year horizon)
Confirm proactive preparation (not just reactive)
evidence: Emerging technology threat assessments
Future threat horizon scanning reports
Pilot/PoC threat models for new AI security technologies
Strategic planning documents incorporating future threat landscape

scoring.yes_if: Systematic emerging threat monitoring, predictive models, strategic integration
scoring.partial_if: Some future-looking analysis but not systematic
scoring.no_if: Only current/known threats, no predictive modeling

success_metrics.target: Document >5 multi-stage attack scenarios for AI security operations
success_metrics.measurement: Count of documented advanced threat scenarios (attack chains, cascades)
success_metrics.data_source: Advanced threat model repository
success_metrics.validation: Independent red team review of scenario realism

success_metrics.target: Contribute >3 unique threat insights to community annually
success_metrics.measurement: Count of intelligence contributions to ISACs or industry groups
success_metrics.data_source: Community participation logs
success_metrics.validation: Community acknowledgment of contributions

success_metrics.target: >60% of predicted threats materialize within 12 months
success_metrics.measurement: (Predicted threats that occurred / Total predictions) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: Threat prediction documents vs. actual threat landscape
success_metrics.validation: Independent validation that threats actually occurred

success_metrics.target: Conduct >2 tabletop exercises annually for AI security failure scenarios
success_metrics.measurement: Count of tabletop exercises completed
success_metrics.data_source: Exercise documentation and after-action reports
success_metrics.validation: Exercise facilitator reports, participant feedback

success_metrics.target: Publish >1 research contribution (paper, talk, tool) annually
success_metrics.measurement: Count of public contributions to AI security knowledge
success_metrics.data_source: Publications, conference presentations, open-source contributions
success_metrics.validation: Public record of contributions (conference schedules, GitHub repos, papers)

desired_outcomes: Proactive Threat Posture: Not surprised by new AI threats, anticipated them, prepared for worst-case scenarios
Industry Leadership: Recognized as thought leader in AI security, contributing to broader community
Resilience Against Advanced Threats: Can withstand sophisticated multi-stage attacks, business can continue even if AI security compromised
Strategic Advantage: Understanding future threat landscape before competitors, prepared for emerging technologies
Collaborative Defense: Part of industry-wide defense ecosystem with early warning from peers

breakdown.predictive_analysis: 80-120 hours (emerging tech monitoring, future threat research)

common_pitfalls: Prediction Speculation: Wild guesses about future threats not grounded in data
Intelligence Sharing One-Way: Only taking from community, not contributing
BCP Lip Service: Plan on paper never tested with realistic scenarios
Industry Contribution Ego: Presenting to boost brand, not help industry, withholding critical information
tools_resources: Advanced threat modeling (Attack trees, MITRE ATT&CK frameworks, PASTA)
Industry ISACs, AI security working groups, OWASP AI Security community
Technology trend reports (Gartner, Forrester), academic research monitoring
Tabletop exercise platforms, incident simulation tools

practices.name: Security Testing
practices.objective: Ensure Security Testing for HAI software
practices.description: Security Testing practices specific to HAI software

maturity_levels.objective: Establish foundational capability to test AI security agents and validate their findings
activities: Implement basic validation process for AI-reported vulnerabilities
Test AI security agents with known vulnerabilities
Establish baseline metrics for AI agent effectiveness
Create feedback loop to AI agent vendors/developers

assessment_criteria.question: Do you perform basic security testing using AI agents?
verification: Review AI security testing tools deployed (SAST, DAST, pentest agents)
Check execution frequency (should be regular, not ad-hoc)
Verify results are collected and reviewed
Sample recent scan reports
evidence: AI security testing tool licenses/contracts
Scan execution logs (last 3 months)
Vulnerability reports generated by AI agents
Evidence of security team reviewing results

scoring.yes_if: AI testing agents deployed, run regularly, results reviewed by security team
scoring.partial_if: AI testing exists but infrequent or results not reviewed
scoring.no_if: No AI security testing or purely manual testing

assessment_criteria.question: Do you validate AI security agent findings for accuracy?
verification: Review validation process documentation
Check sample of validated vulnerabilities (last month)
Verify true/false positive tracking exists
Interview security analysts: Do they validate AI findings?
evidence: Validation process documentation
Tracking spreadsheet/database with validation status
Sample of 20 validated vulnerabilities with true/false positive designation
Analyst interviews confirming validation happens

scoring.yes_if: Regular validation process, tracking system exists, analysts confirm
scoring.partial_if: Some validation but not systematic or tracked
scoring.no_if: AI findings accepted without validation

success_metrics.target: >80% of high-risk applications tested by AI agents
success_metrics.measurement: (Applications with AI testing / Total high-risk applications) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: Application inventory + AI testing coverage report
success_metrics.validation: Cross-check with manual testing coverage

success_metrics.target: >50% of AI-reported vulnerabilities manually validated
success_metrics.measurement: (Validated vulnerabilities / Total AI-reported) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: Vulnerability tracking system with validation status
success_metrics.validation: Audit validation records for completeness

success_metrics.target: Establish baseline (no target yet, just measure)
success_metrics.measurement: (True positives / Total validated) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: Validation tracking data
success_metrics.validation: Independent review of validation accuracy

success_metrics.target: >60% of known vulnerabilities in test environment detected by AI
success_metrics.measurement: (Known vulns detected / Total known vulns) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: Test environment with intentional vulns + AI scan results
success_metrics.baseline: Initial test to establish detection capability
success_metrics.validation: Test environment independently verified

desired_outcomes: Basic Trust in AI Findings: Security team knows AI agents find SOME real vulnerabilities
Visibility into AI Agent Effectiveness: Baseline metrics established for tracking improvement
Feedback to Vendors: Clear communication about blind spots and false positives
Known Limitations Documented: Team aware of what AI agents CAN'T detect with compensating controls
common_pitfalls: Validation Bias: Only validating vulnerabilities that look real, not sampling randomly
Test Environment Divergence: Test environment doesn't match production, unrealistic vulns
No Baseline: Starting improvement without knowing current state
Vendor Blame: Complaining without specific data or examples
tools_resources: Vulnerability management platforms (Jira, ServiceNow)
Test environments (OWASP WebGoat, Juice Shop)
AI Testing Agents: SAST (GitHub Advanced Security, Snyk), DAST (Burp Suite, OWASP ZAP)
Metrics dashboards (Security platforms, BI tools)

maturity_levels.objective: Verify AI security agents are effective at finding real vulnerabilities and resilient against adversarial manipulation
activities: Develop comprehensive test suite for AI agent blind spots
Conduct red team exercises to manipulate AI testing agents
Establish true positive/false positive targets and tracking
Implement cross-validation with manual testing
Create automated feedback loop for AI agent tuning

assessment_criteria.question: Do you test AI security agents for adversarial manipulation?
verification: Review red team reports from last 6 months
Check if prompt injection, data poisoning, evasion tests conducted
Verify manipulation success rate is tracked
Confirm remediation for successful manipulation attempts
evidence: Red team exercise reports (last 2 quarters)
Adversarial test case documentation
Manipulation success rate metrics
Remediation tracking for identified vulnerabilities in AI agents

scoring.yes_if: Regular adversarial testing (quarterly), success rate tracked, remediation performed
scoring.partial_if: Some adversarial testing but infrequent or not comprehensive
scoring.no_if: No adversarial testing of AI agents

assessment_criteria.question: Can you verify AI agents find real vulnerabilities (not just report noise)?
verification: Review true positive rate: Should be >70%
Check validation sample size: >100 validated findings
Verify trend analysis: Is true positive rate improving?
Sample 10 recent vulnerabilities: Confirm validation is accurate
evidence: True positive rate reports (last 3 months)
Validation tracking with statistical confidence
Trend charts showing improvement over time
Independent audit of validation accuracy

scoring.yes_if: True positive rate >70%, large sample size, trend tracked, validation accurate
scoring.partial_if: Some validation but true positive rate <70% or small sample
scoring.no_if: No true positive tracking or rate <50% (mostly noise)

assessment_criteria.question: Do you measure AI agent false negative rate (missed vulnerabilities)?
verification: Review cross-validation with manual testing
Check false negative calculation methodology
Verify false negative rate target exists (<15% is good)
Confirm AI agent improvements to reduce false negatives
evidence: Cross-validation reports comparing AI vs. manual testing
False negative rate calculations
Remediation plans for high false negative categories
Evidence of AI agent tuning based on false negative data

scoring.yes_if: False negative rate measured, target exists, improvement tracking
scoring.partial_if: Some false negative awareness but not systematically measured
scoring.no_if: No false negative measurement (only focus on false positives)

success_metrics.target: AI agents resist >80% of red team manipulation attempts
success_metrics.measurement: ((Total manipulation attempts - Successful manipulations) / Total attempts) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: Red team exercise reports
success_metrics.baseline: Initial red team exercise establishes baseline
success_metrics.validation: Independent red team, documented methodology

success_metrics.target: >75% of AI-reported vulnerabilities are valid (Level 2 target)
success_metrics.measurement: (True positives / Total validated vulnerabilities) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: Vulnerability validation tracking system
success_metrics.validation: Statistically significant sample size (n>100 per month), independent review

success_metrics.target: <15% of real vulnerabilities missed by AI agents
success_metrics.measurement: (Vulnerabilities missed by AI / Total real vulnerabilities) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: Cross-validation: AI testing vs. manual pentesting
success_metrics.validation: Manual pentesting by qualified professionals, documented findings

success_metrics.target: >90% coverage of OWASP Top 10 + AI-specific vulnerabilities
success_metrics.measurement: Vulnerability types detected / Total vulnerability types in checklist
success_metrics.data_source: Test suite results against comprehensive vulnerability checklist
success_metrics.validation: Standard vulnerability taxonomy (OWASP, CWE, MITRE ATLAS)

success_metrics.target: 10% reduction in false positive rate quarter-over-quarter
success_metrics.measurement: ((Previous quarter FP rate - Current quarter FP rate) / Previous quarter FP rate) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: False positive tracking over time
success_metrics.validation: Consistent measurement methodology, documented tuning changes

desired_outcomes: High-Confidence AI Findings: Security team can trust 75%+ of AI-reported vulnerabilities without re-validation
Adversarial Resilience: Attackers cannot easily trick AI security agents, manipulation vectors mitigated
Comprehensive Coverage: AI agents detect wide range of vulnerability types with blind spots compensated
Continuous Improvement: AI agent effectiveness improving over time with data-driven tuning

breakdown.adversarial_testing: 40-60 hours (red team exercises, test case development)

roles_required: AI/ML engineer (AI agent configuration, if applicable)

common_pitfalls: Adversarial Testing Theater: Red team only tries obvious attacks, not realistic
False Positive Obsession: Only focus on reducing FP, ignore false negatives
Tuning Without Validation: Change settings without measuring impact
Sample Size Too Small: Claim percentages based on tiny samples
tools_resources: Adversarial testing frameworks, evasion toolkits, red team playbooks
Professional pentesting services, bug bounty programs
Enhanced vulnerability management platforms, statistical analysis tools
Vendor-provided configuration tools, custom rule development

maturity_levels.objective: Ensure AI security testing is comprehensive, continuous, and drives proactive improvement across the organization
activities: Implement continuous security testing with AI agents in production
Conduct advanced red team exercises including novel attack vectors
Establish AI security testing center of excellence
Integrate AI testing with broader security ecosystem
Benchmark AI testing effectiveness externally

assessment_criteria.question: Is AI security testing continuous (not periodic)?
verification: Review CI/CD integration: AI testing on every build?
Check production monitoring: Runtime AI testing active?
Verify feedback loops: Issues auto-created in tracking system?
Sample 10 recent code deployments: AI testing evidence?
evidence: CI/CD pipeline configuration showing AI testing integration
Production monitoring dashboards with AI testing results
Automated ticket creation from AI findings
Deployment logs showing AI testing gate checks

scoring.yes_if: 100% of deployments tested by AI, production runtime testing active, automated feedback
scoring.partial_if: Some continuous testing but not comprehensive or gaps in coverage
scoring.no_if: Periodic/manual AI testing only, no CI/CD integration

assessment_criteria.question: Do you test for novel and emerging attack vectors with AI agents?
verification: Review red team exercises: Include AI-specific attacks?
Check threat intelligence integration: AI agents updated for new threats?
Verify advanced testing: Supply chain, zero-day simulations?
Confirm innovation: Piloting new AI testing techniques?
evidence: Red team reports covering AI-specific attacks (last 12 months)
Threat intelligence feed integration documentation
Evidence of AI agent updates based on emerging threats
Innovation lab reports or pilot project documentation

scoring.yes_if: Regular advanced testing, threat intelligence integrated, innovation program exists
scoring.partial_if: Some advanced testing but not comprehensive or infrequent
scoring.no_if: Only testing for known/common vulnerabilities

assessment_criteria.question: Do you benchmark AI testing effectiveness externally?
verification: Review external benchmarking participation (last 12 months)
Check comparison against peers or industry standards
Verify third-party validation (external pentests, audits)
Confirm sharing of findings with broader community
evidence: Benchmarking reports comparing to peers
Third-party penetration testing results validating AI effectiveness
Industry contributions (presentations, papers, case studies)
Participation certificates from benchmarking programs

scoring.yes_if: Regular external benchmarking, third-party validation, industry contribution
scoring.partial_if: Some external validation but infrequent or limited
scoring.no_if: No external benchmarking or validation

success_metrics.target: 100% of production releases include AI security testing
success_metrics.measurement: (Releases with AI testing / Total releases) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: CI/CD pipeline logs, deployment tracking
success_metrics.validation: Audit CI/CD logs, verify no bypasses

success_metrics.target: <7 days from vulnerability introduction to AI detection
success_metrics.measurement: Average(Detection date - Introduction date) for all detected vulnerabilities
success_metrics.data_source: Vulnerability tracking with introduction date (from git commits)
success_metrics.validation: Accurate timestamp tracking, validated sample

success_metrics.target: >85% of AI-reported vulnerabilities are valid (Level 3 target)
success_metrics.measurement: (True positives / Total validated vulnerabilities) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: Validation tracking with large sample size
success_metrics.validation: n>200 monthly validations, statistical confidence

success_metrics.target: AI agents detect >50% of novel attacks in red team exercises
success_metrics.measurement: (Novel attacks detected / Total novel attacks) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: Advanced red team reports
success_metrics.baseline: Initial advanced red team establishes baseline
success_metrics.validation: Independent red team, novel attack methodology documented

success_metrics.target: AI testing findings align >90% with third-party pentesting
success_metrics.measurement: Overlap between AI findings and external pentest findings
success_metrics.data_source: External pentest reports + AI testing results comparison
success_metrics.validation: Reputable external pentesting firm, comprehensive scope

desired_outcomes: Proactive Vulnerability Detection: Vulnerabilities found within days of introduction, not months
Industry-Leading Effectiveness: AI testing effectiveness in top quartile vs. peers, externally validated
Resilience Against Advanced Threats: AI agents detect novel attacks, organization prepared for emerging threats
Organizational Security Culture: Developers trust AI testing as quality gate, security embedded in workflow
Comprehensive Security Ecosystem: AI testing integrated with all security tools, unified view, automated response

implementation.cost_external: $150K-$300K (advanced red team, third-party validation, tools, consulting)

common_pitfalls: Continuous Testing Overload: Every build triggers hours of testing, developers bypass gates
Integration Complexity: Too many tools, poor integration, data silos
Benchmarking Gamesmanship: Only benchmark on favorable metrics, compare against weak peers
Innovation Without Validation: Pilot every new tool without validating effectiveness
tools_resources: CI/CD platforms (GitHub Actions, GitLab CI, Jenkins)
Container security (Snyk, Aqua, Prisma Cloud), RASP tools
AI security testing frameworks (Counterfit, ART)
SIEM platforms (Splunk, Elastic), SOAR platforms, GRC platforms
Third-party pentesting firms, industry benchmarking programs
